things.title: What are you reading today?
What will you teach us today?
Know the change you seek to make and the sacrifices for that change.
Marketing your work is where your work begins.
Do the work that matters.
Abundant means; scarce desires.
Take accountability to earn equity.
Find the others.
Make something that you’ll miss.
People don’t buy the best product. They buy the best story.
Gain clarity through articulation.
Tell me 20 things I don’t know.
People crave just the right combination of novelty and familiarly.
Become a lot less relevant to a lot more people and instead become a lot more relevant to a few people.
What are you building?
Your success is largely determined by your ability to speak, write, and the quality of your ideas, in that order.
Change the story, change the experience.
All models are wrong, some models are useful.
Real value comes from the questions you ask, the connections you make, and how well you help people feel understood.
Commit to doing the smallest task not currently within your ability.
Commit to learning the uncomfortable skills.
Commit to consuming uncomfortable ideas and explaining why it makes sense.
Commit to making contact with at least one person whose ideas you admire.
Emotional discomfort comes with doing work you don’t know how to do yet. Progressively overload.
Making people smile and giving them hope is like a magic greater than magic itself.
Breadth of experiences are both key and undervalued. So, take the time to choose where you’d like to focus.

Lean into your experiences.
The dots only connect backward.
There is no such thing as “falling behind.”
We hear what we focus on, and what we hear changes how we experience the world.
Find what’s preventing people from making progress.

Want something to stand out?
Make it ugly.
Create the conditions that make us all better.
Study as if you know nothing. Work as if you can solve anything.
Unless you know why someone made a decision, you can’t conclude that they were wrong.
All returns in life, whether in wealth, relationships, or knowledge come from compound interest.
Needless commitments are more wasteful than needless possessions.
Your current habits are perfectly designed to deliver your current results.
Play stupid games win stupid prizes.
Don’t let your inputs match your outputs. Gain traction and keep ratcheting up and up.
Spend time with people of high intelligence, energy and integrity.
If society can train you, it can train someone else, and replace you.
Do more of whatever you can’t stop thinking about.
Take risks under your own name.
Utilize permissionless leverage: code and media.
People that know the least, tend to talk in absolutes.
Your reputation is a magnet.
Your success depends on the risks you take. Your survival depends on the risks you avoid.
Love challenges, be intrigued by mistakes, enjoy effort, and keep learning.
Aim to be great in 10 years.
Validate and fascinate. Not correct and convince.

Find where you’re going next.
Find what you need to get there.
Find the others.
Opportunities instead of tasks. Chances instead of risks.
If you’re gonna do it, then DO IT.
If it’s obvious, it’s worth stating explicitly.
Put in an unreasonable amount of effort to make sure it’s magical.
Amateurs have a goal. Professionals have a process.
Good habits make time your ally. Bad habits make time your enemy.
There is a large difference between knowing the name of something and knowing something.
We’re all just big, complicated bags of emotion walking around.
If you have a solution you will spend almost all of your time convincing people to use it.
The best way to advance your career is to work.
Approach situations from the opposite end of the natural starting point.
Engage with the world instead of constantly thinking about it.
Sucking at something is the first step towards being sorta good at something.
Tell stories. Make connections. Create experiences.
Marketers sell feelings, status, and connection, not tasks or stuff.
Confidence won’t automatically get you results, but self-doubt sets your ceiling.
Practice is the price you pay today to be better tomorrow.
Embrace and pivot.
If you care enough about your work to be willing to be criticized for it then you’ve done a good days work.
Whatever you repeat, you reinforce.
You know yourself mostly by your thoughts. Everyone else knows you only by your actions.
You can wish away forever, but you’ll never find a thing like today.
Often the only way to do well is to refuse to play.
We’re here to solve the hard problems.
Marketing would be easy if every prospect and customer thought the way you do.
Don’t talk about better, get clear on the story you tell.
